lessons.title: 1. Malware Analysis Fundamentals
lessons.description: Learn the basics of malware analysis and reverse engineering

pages.title: Introduction to Malware Analysis
pages.content: Malware analysis is the process of understanding the behavior and purpose of malicious software. It involves both static and dynamic analysis techniques to understand how malware works.

pages.title: Types of Malware
pages.content: Common types of malware include viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware, spyware, and rootkits. Each type has different characteristics and requires different analysis approaches.

pages.title: Static Analysis
pages.content: Static analysis involves examining malware without executing it. This includes analyzing file structure, strings, imports, and disassembled code to understand its functionality.

pages.title: Dynamic Analysis
pages.content: Dynamic analysis involves running malware in a controlled environment to observe its behavior. This includes monitoring system calls, network activity, and file modifications.

pages.title: Analysis Tools
pages.content: Common malware analysis tools include IDA Pro, Ghidra, Wireshark, Process Monitor, and various sandbox environments. Each tool serves specific analysis purposes.

pages.title: Reverse Engineering
pages.content: Reverse engineering involves analyzing compiled code to understand its original source code and functionality. It's a crucial skill for malware analysts and security researchers.

pages.title: Quiz: Malware Analysis
pages.question: What is the main difference between static and dynamic analysis?

options.text: Static analysis doesn't execute the malware

pages.explanation: Static analysis examines malware without executing it, while dynamic analysis runs the malware in a controlled environment to observe its behavior.
